 Wildlife Conservation Society WCS Canada Oakland Zoo

caption_original:
We are thrilled that so many of you are excited for Canada150 and the free souvenir 2017 Parks Canada Discovery Pass. Due to the exceptionally high volume of Discovery Pass online orders, you may experience delays in accessing the site. 

We wish to remind those who are trying to order their pass online that this is not a limited time offer and encourage you to come back and try again later. If you are planning to visit soon, passes are also available at Parks Canada locations across the country starting January 1, 2017. 

We look forward to welcoming all visitors to experience the best of Canada’s natural and cultural heritage in 2017.

caption_original: Today is National Blueberry Day! Did you know that berries are an important high quality food source for bears? 🐻 By mid-July to early August, the fruits of berry producing shrubs begin to mature. On the drier east slopes of the Rocky Mountains, buffaloberry is most common, and on the moister west slopes of the Rockies blueberry and huckleberry shrubs grow. See our website for tips on being bear aware: http://ow.ly/nPMU30ct438

caption_original: Located on a peninsula jutting out into Lake Erie, Point Pelee is not only the southernmost national park in Canada, it’s the very southern tip of the country itself. Point Pelee is also home to a whopping 66 species at risk – more than any other national park in the country. This includes the monarch butterfly, a species threaten by extreme weather and habitat loss. Point Pelee is working to restore the savannah areas that provide vital habitat for the monarch. #LearnAboutButterfliesDay

caption_original: This day in 1733 marked the first time a lighthouse was lit in what we now call Canada. The Louisbourg Lighthouse that stands today is the third constructed in the very same spot as the original centuries ago. Discover heritage lighthouses across the country: http://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/pp-hl How many have you visited? Fortress of Louisbourg National Historic Site Canada Keep Exploring

caption_original:
Happy World Wildlife Day! #FunFact: To protect whales, such as the St. Lawrence beluga and the blue whale, our staff has been studying... their food!

Why? To identify feeding grounds. The findings were then used to inform the shipping industry, who agreed to reduce the speed of vessels in the main feeding grounds in order to reduce the risk of collisions with whales. This is a great example of how Parks Canada is leading by using science to support wildlife protection.

To learn more about this initiative and other Parks Canada species at risk success stories, visit our website: http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/nature/eep-sar/itm11.aspx.

caption_original: Tomorrow is Auyuittuq's birthday! Well, the anniversary of its creation as a national park. The most accessible of the Nunavut parks, its raw beauty can also be experienced on a spring snowmobile day-trip to the Arctic Circle or summer hike to Ulu Peak. Did you know the Inuktitut word "auyuittuq" means "the land that never melts"? Even so, it's famous for its stunning blooming season in July and early August. Plan your visit: http://ow.ly/2Hcw30aczlb Parks Canada Nunavut

caption_original: On this day in 1813, Laura Secord completed her remarkable 32 km journey, in which she warned the British troops of the Americans' intentions to attack their forces. This feat made her a renowned hero of the War of 1812, and an iconic Canadian historic figure who continues to inspire today!

caption_original:
Fan of Anne and Avonlea? Then this national historic site is for you! Anne of Green Gables fans may recognize Dalvay-by-the-Sea as the fictional “White Sands Hotel.” It was featured in the Anne of Green Gables movies and in the television series Road to Avonlea. Located within Prince Edward Island National Park, Dalvay-by-the-Sea is a unique combination of coastal beauty and exquisite Queen Anne Revival-style architecture! 

To celebrate #Canada150, we’re featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

#DidYouKnow that Glacier National Park’s Mount Macdonald, popular with hikers, skiers and climbers, was named in honour of Sir John A. Macdonald?

Mount Revelstoke and Glacier national parks

©Parks Canada / J. Bolingbroke

caption_original:
Happy International Day of Rock! 🤘 If you're not a musician, rock out by visiting one of our beautiful Rocky Mountain Parks. 🏔 Did you know the Canadian Mountain Parks are a designated UNESCO World Heritage site? 

Some of the best-known mountain scenery on Earth is concentrated in a set of seven parks in the Canadian Rocky Mountains, including four national parks. The Burgess Shale, in Yoho, contains one of the world’s most significant finds of marine fossils.

Photo taken in Yoho National Park. Destination British Columbia

The Burgess Shale, in Yoho, contains one of the world’s most significant finds of marine fossils. Photo taken in Yoho National Park. Destination British Columbia

caption_original:
Have you ever tried snowshoeing? 

Here are 8 reasons why you should:
1) No or very little coordination is required. It’s simple to learn for all ages!
2) Little preparation time needed before leaving on a hike.
3) There’s low risk of injury and it’s easy on joints.
4) It’s a superior calorie-burner - about 500/hour.
5) It provides a great legs and buttocks workout - and arms too, if you add poles.
6) You can explore out-of-the-way places.
7) Snowshoeing is inexpensive - especially compared with other winter sports.
8) It's so much fun!!!
caption_cleaned: Have you ever tried snowshoeing? Here are reasons why you should: ) No or very little coordination is required. It’s simple to learn for all ages! ) Little preparation time needed before leaving on a hike. ) There’s low risk of injury and it’s easy on joints. ) It’s a superior calorie-burner - about /hour. ) It provides a great legs and buttocks workout - and arms too, if you add poles. ) You can elore out-of-the-way places. ) Snowshoeing is ineensive - especially compared with other winter sports. ) It's so much fun!!!

caption_original:
Parks Canada is excited about the reports of the discovery of the wreck of HMS Terror. 

The discovery of HMS Terror would be important for Inuit communities and Canada, reflecting the ongoing and valuable role of Inuit traditional knowledge in the search and making a significant contribution to completing the Franklin story. 

Parks Canada is currently working with our partners to validate the details of the discovery.

Parks Canada is currently working with our partners to validate the details of the discovery.

caption_original: Gros Morne National Park wasn’t named a UNESCO World Heritage site just for its breathtaking beauty. What makes this site remarkable is its geology! This national park is considered a textbook illustration of plate tectonics. Be sure to visit the Gros Morne Discovery Centre to learn why this place rocks! http://ow.ly/caru302eXGf

caption_original:
Tomorrow is Dr. Norman Bethune’s 127th birthday! During the early 20th century, Dr. Bethune became a medical pioneer, advocate for Canada’s universal health care system, and revered Chinese cultural icon. Take a tour of Bethune Memorial House National Historic Site, a charming Victorian-era home set on a manicured property alongside an informative Visitor Centre, and immerse yourself in an incredible legacy of accomplishment that strengthens the bond between nations to this day. http://www.pc.gc.ca/eng/lhn-nhs/on/bethune/visit.aspx 

To celebrate #Canada150, we’re featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

http://ow.ly/xumO30avKyV

caption_original: These interesting beings are called nudibranchs. They’re pleasing to the eye but venomous to the touch! Interesting fact: some species of nudibranchs recycle their prey’s defences! caption_original: Is glamping your thing? Try the Tiny Homes on Wheels at Waterton Lakes National Park this fall! The experimental Tiny Homes on Wheels can each accommodate up to four people, and have separate unique designs. They offer propane heating, a complete kitchen, a toilet and shower. Find out more: http://ow.ly/ilJm303ZBum

caption_original: Did you know? Everything about Wood Buffalo National Park and #UNESCO site is BIG!  It's not only the largest national park in Canada, it's home to the largest land mammal (Wood Bison) and the tallest bird (endangered Whooping Crane) in North America. It also has the largest Dark Sky Preserve in the world AND the world's longest beaver dam!! http://ow.ly/EGNW3043TFz
caption_cleaned: Did you know? Everything about Wood Buffalo National Park and site is BIG! It's not only the largest national park in Canada, it's home to the largest land mammal (Wood Bison) and the tallest bird (endangered Whooping Crane) in North America. It also has the largest Dark Sky Preserve in the world AND the world's longest beaver dam!!

caption_original:
Polar bears are fast sprinters! When trotting along, they can travel at a pace of 30 km/hr, and can sprint at nearly 50 km/hr! 😲 To put that into comparison… the fastest human sprinters can run at just over 35km/hr. #PolarBearWeek Polar Bears International

Learn more about polar bears: http://ow.ly/J70y30gohzz

caption_original:
All aboard! 🚊 The cultural heart of Glacier National Park, Rogers Pass NHS Mount Revelstoke and Glacier national parks, offers a unique history of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, and is a beautiful spot to explore for those who ❤️ to ski. 

But wait… Make sure not to forget your Winter Permit! #DYK? Glacier National Park is home to the world’s largest mobile avalanche control program! Together with the Canadian Armed Forces, Parks Canada conducts avalanche control with artillery to ensure safety of transportation throughout the park, resulting in daily openings and closures. In order to ski in this area, visitors must take part in the Winter Permit System. Learn more about how you can get your permit here: http://ow.ly/Vmnu30gV6eW

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

caption_original: In approximately 30 locations across Ivvavik National Park, Parks Canada installs weatherproof motion-triggered wildlife cameras. As its grand voyage along Canada’s three borders continues, #CanadaC3 begins the sixth leg of its historic journey celebrating #Canada150. 

From July 23rd to 29th, the expedition will travel from Nain to Iqaluit, stopping at the Torngat Mountains National Park.  From the Inuktitut word ‘Torngait’, meaning ‘place of spirits’, this extraordinary site, home to the world’s second oldest rock formation in the world, shall host the expedition on July 25th! 

http://ow.ly/nLYC30dL9Yt

caption_original:
At 44,807 km2, Wood Buffalo National Park is Canada’s largest national park and one of the largest in the world! The park was established in 1922 to protect the free-roaming bison herds of the area. Today, the park supports and protects many unique natural and cultural resources, like the nesting habitat of the last remaining wild migratory flock of whooping cranes left in the world. 

To celebrate #Canada150, we’re featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

caption_original:
Happy birthday to Elk Island National Park!  

With elk, mule deer and moose enclosed within its fenced boundaries, Elk Park became the first federally controlled area in Canada to be enclosed as a big game sanctuary. Elk Island Park, as it was called in 1908, was a wildlife park until it became formally designated as a Dominion Park on this day in 1913! 

To celebrate #Canada150, we’re featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

The Blanding’s turtle is a medium-sized freshwater turtle, which is readily distinguished by its bright yellow throat and chin. They typically live a very long life (80+ years).  
We have taken concrete action at several of our national parks including Kejimkujik National Park in Nova Scotia, and Point Pelee and Georgian Bay Islands National Parks and more recently, in Rouge National Urban Park in Ontario to protect and restore Blanding Turtles and their habitat.  

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

Riding Mountain Park East Gate Registration Complex NHS stands proud as the last remaining early 1930s-style National Park gate! A shining example of the traditional Canadian Rustic Design style of architecture, its logs and stone walls were built by local craftsmen with local materials. Nowadays it still remains as eastern gateway to @RidingNP.

caption_original:
We invite you to explore the Chilkoot Trail NHS! A centuries old path first crossed by Chilkoot Tlingit traders and later stormed by the Klondike Gold Rush stampeders. The Chilkoot Trail starts at tidewater in Dyea, Alaska and ends on the shores of the Southern Lakes headwaters of the mighty Yukon River. Few trails of similar length offer more dramatic changes in climate, terrain and vegetation or more spectacular scenery.

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

Luke: What’s in there? 
Yoda: Only what you take with you.  
Enjoy a hike on Yoda’s home planet, Dagobah, or at a national park near you. Check out Parks Canada’s website for trip planning advice to ensure you make the most out your visit, including tips in case you meet a Bantha or a Ewok on the trail.

caption_original:
Presentation swords like this one are decorative, and were most often presented as gifts for impressive achievements, to be worn on special occasions. This sword was presented by the Legislature of Upper Canada in 1816 in recognition of Lieutenant-Colonel Francis Battersby's services. He was a British Commander who served during the War of 1812. 

Discover more artefacts under our care by following #OurVaults on @PCarchaeology. https://twitter.com/pcarchaeology

This sword was presented by the Legislature of Upper Canada in in recognition of Lieutenant-Colonel Francis Battersby's services. He was a British Commander who served during the War of . Discover more artefacts under our care by following on .

caption_original:
The Fenian Brotherhood was formed in the United States in 1858. They sought independence for Ireland from Britain and the establishment of an Irish Republic. The American Fenians planned a series of raids to seize the transportation network of Canada, in order to force the British to exchange Ireland’s freedom for possession of Canada. They planned and partly executed raids in Ontario, Quebec, Manitoba and the Maritimes in 1866, 1870 and 1871. This extremely rare example of a Fenian jacket was taken from a Fenian prisoner in Quebec in May of 1870. 

Discover more artefacts under our care by following #OurVaults on @PCarchaeology. https://twitter.com/pcarchaeology

They planned and partly executed raids in Ontario, Quebec, Manitoba and the Maritimes in , and . This extremely rare example of a Fenian jacket was taken from a Fenian prisoner in Quebec in May of . caption_original:
Did you know the Massasauga Rattlesnake🐍 is one of Canada's most unusual snakes and one of the most threatened! This solitary, passive and timid rattlesnake relies on camouflage to avoid detection, shaking its tail in warning when it feels threatened.

Preferring flight to confrontation, it rarely strikes, doesn't pursue people and doesn't always inject venom when it bites. #WildlifeWednesday

caption_original:
A landscape and history as diverse as the day is long awaits you at Grasslands National Park, one of our hidden gems to explore in 2017!

With over 70 different species of grass and over 50 different species of wildflowers, Grasslands has an important role in protecting the prairie ecosystem! Discover some of Canada’s rarest wildlife, darkest skies, astonishing dinosaur fossils, over 12,000 teepee rings and varied landscapes, from buttes and valleys to breathtaking badlands.

To celebrate #Canada150, we’re featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

The winter season in Jasper National Park is such a beautiful time to visit. From its snow covered mountain peaks to its lightly dusted forests, the landscape is a winter wonderland awaiting adventure. This is why you shouldn't wait until the summer to explore what they call the gentle giant of the Rockies!

caption_original:
Happy National Wildlife Week! 

The vast majority of whoopers breed in Wood Buffalo National Park, located along the border of Alberta and the Northwest Territories, and they winter only in a small marsh on the coast of Texas.  
We have been working with partners for 50 years to protect their important nesting habitat within Wood Buffalo National Park and to date, our data shows that these recovery efforts are working!

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

caption_original:
On this day in 1966 four Caterpillar tractors began dragging the 1,300-ton S.S. Klondike II from the Whitehorse shipyards to her current location next to the river at the far end of town. Over eight tons of Palmolive Princess Snow Flake soap lubricated the steel cradle and wooden skids on which she moved. It took 5 weeks to complete the move! Now restored to her original 1937 appearance, the S.S. Klondike was designated a National Historic Site in 1967.

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

caption_original: Happy International Archaeology Day! Underwater archaeological excavation at Red Bay National Historic Site began in 1978. Four well-preserved 16th century Basque whaling galleons and four small whaling craft have been found, making it one of the most significant marine archaeological finds in North America. This UNESCO World Heritage Site is also where you might find our most unique red chair view! #IAD2017 @ArchaeologyDay

caption_original:
Is there a more magical place on earth than Nahanni National Park Reserve? We might be biased, but we don’t think so! Nahanni National Park Reserve is considered a paradise for those adventurers who pursue remote wilderness. Alpinists are drawn to the Cirque of Unclimbables, paddlers explore the heart of the reserve and mountaineers trek, compass in hand, across range, meadow and karst. Interpreters located within the park convey the Dene culture to the curious. Want to learn more?  http://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nt/nahanni

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

caption_original: “What in the world are national parks?” was Mabel Williams’ response when she first heard of protected parks. In the 1920s, she went on to explore the parks by foot, by horse, and by car, as research for her guidebooks that became the decade’s centrepiece of tourism promotion for the parks, the Canadian Rockies, and Canada itself. The best job on earth, if you ask us! #EqualityMatters #InternationalWomensDay

caption_original:
The beluga whale, nicknamed the “sea canary” because of its diverse and frequent vocalisations, is a fascinating species which lives in a complex social structure.  With its white skin, prominent forehead and lack of dorsal fin, it is easily recognizable among marine mammals. The St. Lawrence beluga is a year-round resident of the St. Lawrence River and depends on the Saguenay-St. Lawrence Marine Park to feed and rear its young.  

We are working with the Department of Fisheries and Oceans and others to encourage the recovery of this endangered species by enhancing protection of its critical habitat. Awareness campaigns, patrolling and new regulations have reduced the threats on belugas caused by boat traffic.

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

Happy World Turtle Day! Georgian Bay Islands National Park has the largest variety of amphibians and reptiles in Canada. The world’s largest freshwater archipelago, it is home to a boat-access nature preserve situated where the windswept white pines and granite shores of the Canadian Shield turn to dense deciduous woodland. The landscape of Georgian Bay Islands inspired the Group of Seven - let it inspire you! Is this one-of-a-kind place on your #Canada150 bucket list? Ontario Travel 

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

On the west side of Newfoundland's Great Northern Peninsula, you’ll find the crossroads of 6000 years of human history at Port au Choix National Historic Site. Discover one of North America’s most fascinating archaeological finds amid a rugged coastline of unique limestone barrens, forests and bays. Visit ancient burial sites, settlements and view original artifacts, from slate spears to harpoons.

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

caption_original:
The Northern Leopard Frog has a very distinctive call that sounds like a door creaking open, followed by a little chuckle sound.  Once the most wide-spread frog in North America, it started to mysteriously disappear from much of southwestern Canada, including Waterton Lakes National Park in Alberta, in the late 1970s. 

We are taking northern leopard frog egg masses from Grasslands National Park, where the frog populations are healthy, and bringing them back to Waterton Lakes.  Our scientists are also working alongside the Calgary Zoological Society to take the search for the missing frogs to the genetic level using an innovative environmental DNA (eDNA) monitoring technique.  

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9
caption_cleaned: The Northern Leopard Frog has a very distinctive call that sounds like a door creaking open, followed by a little chuckle sound. We are taking northern leopard frog egg masses from Grasslands National Park, where the frog populations are healthy, and bringing them back to Waterton Lakes. Our scientists are also working alongside the Calgary Zoological Society to take the search for the missing frogs to the genetic level using an innovative environmental DNA (eDNA) monitoring technique. caption_original: For his service in the “Black Battalion,” Private George A. Downey was awarded the British War Medal and the Victory Medal. Prior to joining the No. 2 Construction Battalion at Truro in 1917, White was an active voice against racial discrimination in the Canadian Expeditionary Force. He was a trail blazer. Remember: never feed wildlife and always keep a safe distance. If you’re photographing wildlife, use a telephoto lens so you don’t disrupt animals in their homes.

Parks Canada WPG Manitoba

Today marks the beginning of Women’s History Month! There are many incredible women who have been designated National Historic Persons, including Carrie Matilda Derick. 

She was the first woman to attain the rank of professor at a Canadian university. This pioneer in the field of genetics attained international recognition as a botanist and made an outstanding contribution to both academic and popular science: ow.ly/zVn830fsOEt

Stay tuned for more historic women on our social media channels! Women in Canada

caption_original:
Spread across 22,000 square kilometres of Baffin Island’s northeastern coast, Sirmilik National Park is one of Nunavut’s most accessible parks. Paddle among seals and floating ice, ski across glaciers, hike where snowy owls hunt, travel by snowmobile to the floe edge… Visiting Sirmilik is the ultimate Arctic adventure under the Midnight Sun.

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

caption_original: Despite its scary looks, the Wolffish is rarely aggressive! In fact, #wolffish are model parents that take special care of their eggs as they develop. They can be found in Canada's Pacific and Atlantic Oceans and unfortunately, some members of this family are considered #speciesatrisk. #NatureForAll #wildlifewednesday

Love paddling? Aulavik National Park is home to the 160 km-long Thomsen River – one of the continent’s most northerly navigable rivers! This beautiful park encompasses a variety of landscapes from fertile river valleys to polar deserts, buttes and badlands, rolling hills, and bold seacoasts.

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts... Stay tuned!

Did you know today is #WorldJumpDay?
Created in 2006, it was claimed that if 600 million people from the western hemisphere jumped simultaneously, the Earth would move out of its orbit, into one that would not cause global warming. The story was later revealed to be a hoax. But it’s still fun, so jump! 

Photo taken in Georgian Bay Islands National Park.

caption_original: On January 20 1850, the HMS Investigator set sail in hopes of finding the lost #FranklinExpedition, and more importantly, the Northwest Passage. The Investigator was abandoned in 1853 when it became stuck in the ice of Mercy Bay.  In 2010, we discovered the HMS Investigator just north of #Aulavik National Park. Parks Canada NWT #OTD #TodayinHistory

caption_original:
100 years ago, three years into the Great War, the British imperial forces launched a campaign against the enemy in Flanders, Belgium. They were later joined by the Canadian Corps who, although pressed for time, thoroughly prepared and mounted an attack on October 26. Slogging through thick mud and intense enemy fire, they succeed in capturing Passchendaele Ridge on November 10th, but at great cost: nearly 16,000 Canadians were killed, wounded or went missing. Canada Remembers

Learn more: http://ow.ly/cEDt30gocG2

caption_original: Today is the International Day for Biodiversity! When it comes to biodiversity, there’s a whole other world beneath the surface! #DYK the spiral tusk of a narwhal is actually its tooth? It’s also covered in nerve endings (it can “feel”!), it’s used to strike fish for feeding, AND is used in mating rituals! Now that’s a multi-purpose tusk!! #MarineMonday

This month we’re celebrating the announcement of the official boundary for our next National Marine Conservation Area - Tallurutiup Imanga/#LancasterSound! We’ll be featuring everything from species that call this northern gem home, to its rich cultural history!

caption_original:
It's time for #TriviaTuesday! This isolated post was a vital fur trade hub for more than 250 years... What is it called? #NHS100

ANSWER: It's York Factory National Historic Site in Manitoba! Between 1684 and its closing 273 years later in 1957, York Factory served as a trading post. From 1812 to the late 1850s, it was also the main entry point for European immigration to Western Canada.

caption_original:
During the mid-16th century, large numbers of right and bowhead whales drew whalers from the Basque region of Spain and France to the Strait of Belle Isle, where they established a major whaling port at Red Bay. For some 70 years, Basque whalers made the dangerous, month-long journey across the Atlantic to hunt whales and produce the oil that lit the lamps of Europe. See original Basque artifacts, remains, and restored chalupa at Red Bay National Historic Site in Newfoundland. 

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

For some years, Basque whalers made the dangerous, month-long journey across the Atlantic to hunt whales and produce the oil that lit the lamps of Europe. See original Basque artifacts, remains, and restored chalupa at Red Bay National Historic Site in Newfoundland. To celebrate , we're featuring ALL of our + places across our social media accounts. caption_original:
What is the tallest bird in North America? The Whooping Crane can grow up to 4.9 ft with a 7.5 ft wingspan. 

A record number of the endangered whooping cranes was found in Wood Buffalo National Park during the 2017 nesting survey carried out with the Canadian Wildlife Service. This year’s survey found 98 nests, an increase of 16 over the previous record of 82 set in 2014!
#WildlifeWednesday

Learn more about this cool #SpeciesAtRisk: http://ow.ly/e6Bg30gofLC

caption_original:
It's #NamesakeDay! Did you know that many of our national historic forts and national parks have namesake merchant vessels? Among others, Banff Park, Cape Breton, and Green Gables Park, named quite evidently after one of Canada's most popular heroines! These vessels contributed to securing Allied victory in 1945, a legacy with which Parks Canada is proud to associate. 

Library and Archives Canada
Royal Canadian Navy

Happy International Inuit Day! Did you know that traditional Inuit knowledge helps protect endangered Peary caribou in Qausuittuq National Park?

Qausuittuq (pronounced: Kow-soo-ee-took) means “place where the sun doesn't rise” in Inuktitut, in reference to the fact that the sun stays below the horizon for several months in the winter. Parks Canada Nunavut

Appreciate the Rectory’s distinctive Red River architecture and learn about the role that the Church Missionary Society and the Church of England played in the lives of the Red River settlers in the 19th century at this Winnipeg treasure!

Prince Albert National Park was officially opened on this day, 1928 by Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King. This park offers accessible wilderness and extensive outdoor recreation in central Saskatchewan. Hike boreal forests, canoe pristine lakes and see free-range bison, with the town of Waskesiu as a convenient base. Can’t visit this year? Make a date for their 90th in 2018!

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

http://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/sk/princealbert

caption_original:
Today in history: Gulf Islands National Park Reserve was established on this day in 2003! Eagles and seabirds swirl in the skies above the Salish Sea, the waters teeming with seals, otters, orcas and pods of porpoises. Kayak, hike or cycle a lush paradise with rare eco-systems. The forested Gulf Islands are laced with trails leading to mountaintop viewpoints, you don't want to miss out on this hidden gem: http://ow.ly/GVt130bkvnA Destination British Columbia

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

caption_original: With rolling hills and sweeping valleys, the South Okanagan offers a stunning landscape ranging from near-desert to rich forests of ponderosa pine and Douglas fir that support an incredible range of rare wildlife and plants. The South Okanagan is one of Canada’s most unique habitats and has sustained Syilx/Okanagan communities for thousands of years! Haven’t had the pleasure of seeing it yourself? This video will make you feel like you’re there! Check it out!

caption_original: It’s National Frozen Food Day! Did you know flash-freezing technology was inspired by Inuit ice-fishing practices in Canada? Rock caches are a traditional means of storing food in the North. Natural gaps in between rocks channel air flow, acting like a coolant, to keep food fresh or frozen. Tuktut Nogait National Park is home to an area called “Many Caches,” where you can find, you guessed it, many, many caches! Who knew areas like this are to thank for your modern-day frozen dinners!

caption_original:
This V-E Day, we’re remembering the #HomeportHeroes who served in Canada’s Merchant Navy and aided Allied victory in the Second World War. 

From December 1941 until the end of the war in 1945, Canadian shipyards on both coasts, and along the St. Lawrence River, undertook a massive emergency shipbuilding campaign to deliver hundreds of desperately-needed vessels to support the Allied war effort. Naval ships like destroyer HMCS Haida National Historic Site escorted merchant convoys to protect against submarine and air attacks. #LestWeForget http://ow.ly/79eS30brkUz
caption_cleaned: This V-E Day, we’re remembering the who served in Canada’s Merchant Navy and aided Allied victory in the Second World War. From December until the end of the war in , Canadian shipyards on both coasts, and along the St. Lawrence River, undertook a massive emergency shipbuilding campaign to deliver hundreds of desperately-needed vessels to support the Allied war effort. Naval ships like destroyer HMCS Haida National Historic Site escorted merchant convoys to protect against submarine and air attacks.

caption_original:
Happy #WorldOctopusDay🐙! British Columbia is home to the world’s largest species of octopus – the Giant Pacific Octopus! Masters of camouflage, these 8-tentacled creatures can change colours and textures to blend into their surroundings in seconds! If you’re lucky, you may have the chance to see them at Gwaii Haanas - Islands of Beauty during diving season! 

Photo credit: ©Jackie Hildering; The Marine Detective

caption_original: The Black-footed ferret, a solitary and nocturnal small mammal, is one of North America’s most endangered species. caption_original:
Kootenae House was a declared a National Historic Site in 1934. Today the site is marked by a stone cairn, which bears a National Historic Sites of Canada plaque. The site is located just north of Invermere, British Columbia and is situated on a grass-covered terrace, surrounded by meadows and forests and contained within the Columbia Valley.

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

What are NMCAs? National marine conservation areas (NMCAs) represent the diversity of Canada’s oceans and Great Lakes! We want to protect and conserve marine ecosystems, all while providing opportunities for you to enjoy them in ecologically sustainable ways.

This month we’re highlighting national marine conservation areas for #NMCANovember! We’re featuring the species that call these places home, and the research being done to protect them! To learn more about the NMCA program: ow.ly/Cjft30grJJJ

Join us in commemorating the service and sacrifice of Canadians during the First World War. 

Today, historic plaques were unveiled by Minister McKenna to recognize the national historic significance of Aboriginal Military Service during the First World War, the Voluntary Aid Detachments and the Canadian War Memorials Fund. 

Their important contributions during WW1 helped define who we are as a people today.

caption_original:
Kenow Fire - Waterton Lakes National Park: September 8, 2017; 19:15hr
Parks Canada and RCMP have safely evacuated all residents and non-essential personnel from the park. The Waterton townsite is secured. Admittance at the gate is limited to essential personnel. Intense fire behavior and low visibility caused a risk to safety. To ensure safety, Parks Canada evacuated Waterton.  We understand this is a stressful situation and thank everyone for their cooperation, making this a safe and efficient evacuation process.
The fire did not cross Sage Pass or South Kootenay Pass into the park and helicopters were able to bucket water later in the afternoon. Fire crews enhanced Waterton’s infrastructure and facility protection. Yesterday afternoon we successfully burned out approximately 30 hectares of vegetation near South Kootenay Pass, removing this fuel in anticipation of increasing wind and fire behaviour today. Burning these fuels under calmer conditions increased our chances of holding the fire at this location. Weather conditions are expected to increase fire behaviour for the next two days:
http://www.pc.gc.ca/apps/scond/cond_e.asp?oid=29170&opark=100429

To ensure safety, Parks Canada evacuated Waterton. We understand this is a stressful situation and thank everyone for their cooperation, making this a safe and efficient evacuation process. The fire did not cross Sage Pass or South Kootenay Pass into the park and helicopters were able to bucket water later in the afternoon. Fire crews enhanced Waterton’s infrastructure and facility protection. Burning these fuels under calmer conditions increased our chances of holding the fire at this location. Weather conditions are eected to increase fire behaviour for the next two days: 29

Kluane National Park and Reserve – high in the mountains of southwest Yukon – is a land of extremes. The park is home to Canada’s highest peak, its largest ice field and North America’s most genetically diverse grizzly population. With exceptional day hikes and highway-side scenery, Kluane awes from every angle.

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

caption_original:
Instantly captivating, Mingan Archipelago National Park Reserve in Québec features colossal limestone outcroppings that evoke landscapes from primeval times. Frolicking whales and seals enliven the vast, blue horizon, while over 1,000 islands and islets enchant visitors with their unique flora and seabird colonies. Discover this timeless natural wonder aboard a sea expedition or by exploring the many island nature trails!

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

caption_original:
As an active participant in preserving and presenting the country’s military heritage, we commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Second World War by launching Home Port Heroes. This initiative is a way to honour the sacrifices made by the men and women who served in, and built the cargo ships of the Merchant Navy and highlights the historic connection between merchant vessels and Parks Canada’s network of treasured places. 

Follow #HomePortHeroes to find out more about the amazing contributions of Canada’s Merchant Navy during the Second World War. 

http://www.pc.gc.ca/en/culture/historique-historic/mer-port

This initiative is a way to honour the sacrifices made by the men and women who served in, and built the cargo ships of the Merchant Navy and highlights the historic connection between merchant vessels and Parks Canada’s network of treasured places. Follow to find out more about the amazing contributions of Canada’s Merchant Navy during the Second World War.

caption_original:
Artist / filmmaker / explorer Cory Trepanier's fourth painting expedition of his "Into The Arctic" project begins with two weeks canoeing the Thomsen River in Aulavik National Park on the north end of Banks Island. 
In part 1, Cory and his crew land at the park’s green cabin and set off by canoe. During these first few days downriver, they encounter muskox, peregrine falcons and explore the vast arctic tundra. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R2Eg-_XwRfk

caption_original:
We’re celebrating #InuvialuitDay! We’re proud to cooperatively manage the beautiful Tuktut Nogait NP with the Inuvialuit. The landscape and wildlife of the 18,890 sq km national park is seen by those privileged few willing to travel 170 kilometres north of the Arctic Circle. The landscape features rolling hills, three major rivers, steep canyons, waterfalls, rare Bluenose west caribou and the continent’s fiercest predators. 

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

caption_original: Before enlisting in the Great War, British-born George Pearkes (1888-1984) immigrated to Alberta and served with the Royal North-West Mounted Police (forerunner of the RCMP). In 1915, he enlisted with the 2nd Canadian Mounted Rifles in British Columbia. Pearkes was awarded the Victoria Cross at Passchendaele, Belgium, in October 1917 “For most conspicuous bravery and skilful handling of the troops under his command”. He continued to serve during the Second World War then began a long career in politics. Canada Remembers

Pearkes was awarded the Victoria Cross at Passchendaele, Belgium, in October “For most conspicuous bravery and skilful handling of the troops under his command”. caption_original:
Not long after gold was discovered in large quantities in the Klondike, dredges were brought into the Yukon. One of the two dozen dredges that worked this area, Dredge No. 4 is 2/3 the size of a football field and more than seven stories high! It could dig in an hour what took three men all day. Find out more about the Klondike National Historic Sites: http://ow.ly/QQab30b3p3K Parks Canada Yukon Travel Yukon 

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

caption_original: From 1914 to 1918, Fort George and Fort Mississauga National Historic Sites formed Camp Niagara, which served as a military training camp for 14,000 Canadian soldiers. Many of them were sent overseas to serve their country on the battlefields of Europe, including #Vimy Ridge, in 1917. #Vimy100

First built during the War of 1812 to defend the St. Lawrence River shipping route from attack by the United States, Fort Wellington National Historic Site helped thwart another American invasion during the 1837-38 Upper and Lower Canada rebellions. Take part in military drill, witness a cannon firing, savour period treats cooked over an open fire, or play games from long ago: the possibilities are endless! http://ow.ly/UNP130bkHgQ #NHS100 Ontario Travel

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

Scottish-Canadian Colin Barron (1893-1958) enlisted for military service in the First World War and eventually found himself at Passchendaele. With great determination he rushed the enemy, capturing several machine guns. This earned him the Victoria Cross. Barron served his country again during the Second World War. 
Canada Remembers #VeteransWeek

On #WorldFishMigrationDay, we highlight the American Eel!
This eel faces a number of threats, such as obstacles in freshwater preventing its upstream migration, mortality due to hydroelectric power plant turbines, fisheries, contaminants, swim bladder parasites, climate change and changes in ocean conditions. Collecting data in order to properly assess the American Eel's status has become a necessity: http://ow.ly/PWSC300i9XU World Fish Migration Day #SpeciesAtRisk #FishMigration #WFMD2016

caption_original:
Time for a #Canada150 history lesson! The Battle of Tourond’s Coulee/Fish Creek National Historic Site commemorates the place – la coulée des Tourond – where on April 24, 1885, Métis led by Gabriel Dumont, and Cree and Dakota First Nations, held back the advancing North West Field Force. It was the first time the Métis encountered the Canadian military. National Historic Sites in Saskatchewan

To celebrate #Canada150, we’re featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

caption_original:
Ancient Murrelets (or Night Birds in the Haida language) – are a handsome black and white seabird of the North Pacific:  the "penguin" of Canada. Ancient Murrelet colonies in Gwaii Haanas are threatened by invasive rats that arrived with the first sailing ships. These birds are a barometer of the health, both of the marine ecosystems and the remote islands on which they breed. 
With the Haida Nation and several Canadian and international partners, we have successfully restored breeding habitat for the Ancient Murrelet on three islands.

Follow our tips on how to interact with #wildlife in our parks: http://ow.ly/INcO30aFLy9

caption_original: All her life, Katharine McLennan nurtured a deep passion and commitment towards the history and preservation of the Fortress of Louisbourg in Cape Breton, where she was from. For years, she did extensive research to help tell the story of Louisbourg, and, after World War I, she was at the forefront of a civil group aiming to preserve the Fortress of Louisbourg site. Their work led to the opening of the Louisbourg Museum in 1936 and the partial reconstruction of the Fortress in the 1960s. Katharine was named "Honorary Curator" of the museum and served in this capacity for over twenty years. #EqualityMatters #InternationalWomensDay
caption_cleaned: All her life, Katharine McLennan nurtured a deep passion and commitment towards the history and preservation of the Fortress of Louisbourg in Cape Breton, where she was from. For years, she did extensive research to help tell the story of Louisbourg, and, after World War I, she was at the forefront of a civil group aiming to preserve the Fortress of Louisbourg site. Their work led to the opening of the Louisbourg Museum in and the partial reconstruction of the Fortress in the s. Katharine was named "Honorary Curator" of the museum and served in this capacity for over twenty years.

caption_original: Born in Liverpool, UK, Hugh McKenzie (1885-1917) immigrated to Canada and joined the Princess Patricia’s Canadian Light Infantry in 1914. While fighting at Passchendaele, Belgium, McKenzie captured strategic locations from the enemy. It was while leading a frontal assault that he was struck down not surviving to receive in person the Victoria Cross awarded to him. Canada Remembers

What kind of camper are you? 

The NEOPHYTE: you have no idea how to set up a tent and quite frankly, you’re not sure if you have the skills to survive. Well, it’s never too late to try camping, especially with our #LearnToCamp events! http://ow.ly/FD7q30bSBrK 

The ADVENTUROUS: the least amount of people you see the better. You want to immerse yourself in nature and forget what a toilet looks like. http://ow.ly/h1rM30bSBqm 

The EXTRAVAGANT: your tent just doesn’t get that much like on Instagram anymore? It’s time to switch things up with one of our new and unique accommodations in select parks. http://ow.ly/K2KW30bSBuf 

Whatever the type, we have the accommodation for you! Reserve your spot now and celebrate #Canada150 with us this year! #CampingWeekCA

caption_original: During the First World War, Winnipeg native Christopher O’Kelly (1895-1922) enlisted with the 144th Battalion (Winnipeg Rifles) and later transferred to the 52nd Infantry Battalion. In October 1917, O’Kelly led his troops in capturing enemy positions and guns near Passchendaele, Belgium, and resisting fierce counterattacks for which he was bestowed the Victoria Cross. O’Kelly returned home to a hero’s welcome in 1918. Only a few years later, while on a prospecting trip, he was lost on a lake in northern Ontario during a storm. Canada Remembers
caption_cleaned: During the First World War, Winnipeg native Christopher O’Kelly (1895-1922) enlisted with the th Battalion (Winnipeg Rifles) and later transferred to the nd Infantry Battalion. In October , O’Kelly led his troops in capturing enemy positions and guns near Passchendaele, Belgium, and resisting fierce counterattacks for which he was bestowed the Victoria Cross. O’Kelly returned home to a hero’s welcome in . Only a few years later, while on a prospecting trip, he was lost on a lake in northern Ontario during a storm. Canada Remembers

caption_original: Lester B. Pearson – our country’s 14th Prime Minister – was a world statesman and a proud Canadian. He is someone who left a larger-than-life mark, not only on Canada, but on the global community. His lifetime accomplishments and legacy were recognised today at the National Arts Centre / Centre national des Arts in Ottawa. Two plaques commemorating some of his achievements were unveiled and the former prime minister was honoured as a person of national historic significance.

Uncover the tale of Le grand dérangement through engaging multimedia. Admire the statue of Evangeline, heroine of an epic Longfellow poem. View impressive artefacts and statues, storytellers of a turbulent history. Located in the heart of a UNESCO World Heritage Site, this is Grand-Pré National Historic Site—once the epicentre of Acadian culture and now the most significant memorial to their tragic upheaval.

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

caption_original:
Roughly 30 kilometres southeast of Montréal, Fort Chambly National Historic Site rises proudly at the foot of the Richelieu River rapids. Built in 1711 to defend the colony, this stone fortification was preceded by three wooden forts. The fort has preserved the main elements of its original architecture so that you truly feel like you’re walking in the steps of a French infantryman from the 18th century.

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

Did you know the remaining structures at Jasper House were destroyed in 1909? A party of surveyors to the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway converted materials from the surviving cabin into a raft. It is now an archaeological site with few remaining vestiges of the past but a strong sense of #history. #JasperHouseNHS

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

caption_original:
Collisions between ships and other whales are a threat to marine mammals. ⚠️🐳 For species at risk, the loss or injury of even a few individuals can seriously affect the population. To help reduce the risk of collision at Saguenay-St. Lawrence Marine Park, we worked together with the shipping industry to propose a speed reduction – resulting in a nearly 40% decrease in the risk of collisions! #MarineMonday

To learn more about the management of ships and whales in the St. Lawrence estuary: ow.ly/63rO30gNAQY

This month we’re highlighting national marine conservation areas for #NMCANovember! We’re featuring the species that call these places home, and the research being done to protect them!

caption_original:
Hey #Toronto! Join us at Rouge National Urban Park for #BioBlitz Canada June 24-25 from noon until noon and help us count and celebrate the amazing diversity of life found across Canada! A BioBlitz is an event that focuses on finding and identifying as many species as possible in a specific area over a short period of time. At a BioBlitz, scientists, families, students, teachers, and other community members work together to get an overall count of the plants, animals, fungi, and other organisms that live in a place. Registration for scientists and skilled naturalists is now open! For folks of all ages wanting to learn more identification and field work skills, registration for Guided Bioblitz sessions opens March 21.
To register as a scientist visit www.ontariobioblitz.ca. The Rouge is hosting one of 30 Bioblitz events happening across the country as part of Canada 150 celebrations. Visit www.bioblitzcanada.ca to find a Bioblitz near you!
A special thanks to our event partners - Royal Ontario Museum, Canadian Wildlife Federation, The Toronto Zoo, BIObus_Canada, and Toronto and Region Conservation (TRCA).

At a BioBlitz, scientists, families, students, teachers, and other community members work together to get an overall count of the plants, animals, fungi, and other organisms that live in a place. Registration for scientists and skilled naturalists is now open! For folks of all ages wanting to learn more identification and field work skills, registration for Guided Bioblitz sessions opens March . To register as a scientist visit . caption_original:
Happy Halloween! Did you know it’s also the last day of Bat Week??

As part of a landscape restoration project at Georgian Bay Islands National Park, staff needed to find out if bats were taking up residence in an old maintenance shed. The park’s Resource Conservation team used an ultrasonic acoustic detector and found Little Brown Bats sleeping in the building. They were able to determine exactly when the bats moved out in the fall, so while the bats were away for winter vacation down south, staff installed 'bat boxes' all around the area so they had nice new homes to move into when they returned in the spring. #BatWeek
caption_cleaned: Happy Halloween! Did you know it’s also the last day of Bat Week?? As part of a landscape restoration project at Georgian Bay Islands National Park, staff needed to find out if bats were taking up residence in an old maintenance shed. The park’s Resource Conservation team used an ultrasonic acoustic detector and found Little Brown Bats sleeping in the building. They were able to determine exactly when the bats moved out in the fall, so while the bats were away for winter vacation down south, staff installed 'bat boxes' all around the area so they had nice new homes to move into when they returned in the spring.

Who knew? Hollywood blockbuster Dunkirk portrays the turmoil of this harrowing episode of the Second World War. Canadian J. Campbell Clouston, commander in the Royal Navy, was not only there, but was instrumental in the “Miracle at Dunkirk,”  which saw the evacuation of more than 338,000 troops from this French port.

Today, an interpretive panel unveiling ceremony was held at the Lachine Canal to honour this true #Hometownhero. Learn more about J. Campbell Clouston on our website: http://bit.ly/2ya9Hl1

Explore Canada’s history at Woodside National Historic Site, in Kitchener, Ontario, the boyhood home of William Lyon Mackenzie King, Canada’s tenth, and longest-serving Prime Minister. This lovingly preserved Victorian home, filled with King family heirlooms and period reproductions, and set on 11.5 acres of mature forest, is a portal to the Victorian era in Canada.

To celebrate #Canada150, we’re featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Did you know 2017 also marks the centennial of national historic sites? Stay tuned!

caption_original:
Fire crews continue to do everything possible to slow the progress of the wildfire and protect critical infrastructure, park resources, and the community of Waterton.

Kenow Fire Information Update – Unified Command: September 11, 2017; 19:15 

FIRE MOVEMENT AND BEHAVIOUR 
• Fire is now firmly established in the Cameron Valley along the Akamina Parkway. 
• There is also fire in the Tamarack Basin which is expected to grow and move into the Blakiston Valley and towards the Red Rock Parkway. 
• We continue to monitor the fire progress. 
• Structural protection units will be activated if necessary. 
• Extensive infrastructure and facility protection is installed within the townsite including high volume pump and sprinkler systems around the perimeter of town. 
• Highways 5 and 6 are now closed at the boundaries of Waterton Lakes National Park. 
• We are expecting similar weather and intense fire behaviour tomorrow. 

SMOKE 
• Intense fire behaviour is generating significant smoke. Wind direction and temperature inversions may result in low-lying smoke in areas north of Waterton, especially at night. 
• Exercise caution while driving in the area, especially at night. Check AB 511 for driving conditions. Speed limits or closures may be put in place. 
• Wildfire smoke affects people differently. People with pre-existing health conditions or sensitivities to air pollution are at risk of worsened symptoms from smoke exposure. For smoke and air quality alerts visit: www.airhealth.ca 

WHAT’S OPEN AND CLOSED… 
• Waterton Lakes National Park is Closed: www.parkscanada.ca/waterton-kenow-fire 
• Calgary Forest Protection Area south of Highway 532 is Closed: http://srd.web.alberta.ca/calgary-area-update

To subscribe or unsubscribe to these updates contact the Fire Information Officer assistant at elisabeth.caron@pc.gc.ca or 819-247-0075. For media inquiries contact the Fire Information Officer at john.stoesser@pc.gc.ca or 403-859-5127. For general inquiries, call our Information Line at 403-859-5109 or kenowfire.waterton@pc.gc.ca

http://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/ab/waterton/securite-safety/feu-fire-kenow

caption_original: #FunFact: The Pitcher's Thistle flowers only once, for 8 years! Fit’s in bloom from the time the thistle is 2 until it's 10 years old. This endangered species can be found in the fragile dune ecosystems of the upper great lakes, and we’re undertaking work to recover the species at Pukaskwa National Park! #WildlifeWednesday

caption_original: What an amazing morning with Parks Canada WPG ! In partnership with the Manitoba Metis Federation (Official) and Louis Riel Institute at Riel House National Historic Site, we had the pleasure of hosting Minister Catherine McKenna for a special visit at Riel House National Historic Site. We heard tales of Louis Riel’s life and his struggle for Métis rights. We travelled through history! Thank you all. It was a fun, friendly and instructive morning!

We heard tales of Louis Riel’s life and his struggle for Métis rights. We travelled through history! Thank you all. It was a fun, friendly and instructive morning!

caption_original:
Did you know Banff National Park created a special refuge for a species at risk – the westslope cutthroat trout? 

In Alberta alone, westslope cutthroat trout occupy less than 10% of their historical range. Westslope cutthroat trout remain in only about 55 small locations in Alberta, ten of which are in Banff National Park. Parks Canada is therefore an important partner in recovery efforts for this species! Learn more: http://ow.ly/KJWbQ #WildlifeWednesday

Do you make a beeline for the water’s edge when visiting a beautiful place like Mingan Archipelago National Park Reserve? There’s so much to explore in and around the water, and water play can lead to fun with science too.

This #ClubParka activity gives budding scientists a chance to conduct an experiment, make predictions and observations, and try to figure out why things happen the way they do! It’s even more fun if your kids gather the items to test themselves – which ones will sink and which will float?

http://www.pc.gc.ca/en/serapprocher-connect/parka/clubparka/activ-02

Snapping the perfect shot for #NaturePhotographyDay isn’t easy! One way we suggest to capture the best of nature is to explore one of our national parks at twilight 🌅! 

As the sun sets, you’ll have a much better chance of spotting wildlife as they often avoid the midday sun! Just make sure to give all wildlife plenty of room to travel freely – our national parks are their homes! #KeepWildlifeWild

Photo taken at Nahanni National Park Reserve Parks Canada NWT

caption_original: We love keeping our national parks free of waste, and we love making camping even easier for you! A number of our sites offer a variety of equipped camping options so you can leave the plastic cutlery and paper plates at the store, and save space in your home if you don’t own all the gear you need! The Fortress of Louisbourg National Historic Site even offers 18th century equipped camping for the history lover in your family. Check it out! #EnviroWeek http://ow.ly/jasf300XA2g

caption_original:
Earlier today, a special ceremony was held at the Beaubassin and Fort Lawrence National Historic Sites to commemorate the importance of Beaubassin as a place of national historic significance, and to official open the view park at the location.

On the photo, from left to right:
Mathieu D'Astous (Visitor Experience Manager, NHS),  Bill Casey (MP for Cumberland-Colchester), His Honour The Honourable Arthur J. LeBlanc (Lieutenant Governor of Nova Scotia), Daniel Watson (CEO, Parks Canada), Géraldine Arsenault (Field Unit Superintendent), Anne-Marie Lane Jonah (Historian), Her Honour Mrs. Patsy LeBlanc (Wife of the Lieutenant Governor of Nova Scotia) and Gilbert Sewell (Representative from the Mi’kmaq community, from Pabineau, NB)

caption_original: Here’s another #EnviroWeek camping hack to cut down on camping waste! Find yourself bringing lots of gear to prepare your camping meals? Take a bit of time to prep your food at home before you go! Packing pre-chopped veggies or cracking eggs into a mason jar before you go means more time to enjoy your camping trip, more fuel for your compost at home, and less to carry around!
caption_cleaned: Here’s another camping hack to cut down on camping waste! Find yourself bringing lots of gear to prepare your camping meals? Take a bit of time to prep your food at home before you go! Packing pre-chopped veggies or cracking eggs into a mason jar before you go means more time to enjoy your camping trip, more fuel for your compost at home, and less to carry around!

Never been camping? Don't let the summer go by without spending a night in the great outdoors! Our Learn to Camp program will show you the ropes: how to pitch a tent, cook outside, and more! 
This weekend, we're holding workshops in Elk Island National Park and Lévis Forts National Historic Site, you can still sign up! Next weekend we're at Riding Mountain National Park and Lachine Canal National Historic Site.
Here's the full list of dates, find out if there's a Learn to Camp workshop happening near you! http://ow.ly/gYMk301654M
